title: Ticket #3927: how do I know if my collector is unable to keep up with incoming ads?
description:
This issue should ultimately be resolved via a documentation update either in the manual or the wiki.

The question is: what exactly can/should I monitor in the CollectorLog or collector ad to tell me if the collector is dropping updates, how many it's dropping, and at what rate?

The reason I need to know is that I'm trying to ratchet down my CLASSAD_LIFETIME in order to deal with a very large pool of opportunistic resources that regularly come and go without warning (#3926). But I don't know how far I can ratchet down CLASSAD_LIFETIME and *_UPDATE_INTERVAL before the collector is unable to keep up and starts to drop incoming ads, because I don't know how to monitor that.
remarks:
2015-Jan-12 10:09:25 by smoler:
To monitor this information, use 

   condor_status -l <machine name>  | condor_updates_stats --interval=300

This will list state changes of received versus missed updates to the collector.

2015-Jan-12 14:29:47 by gthain:
Is this with UDP or TCP updates? I'm beginning to think that we should always up date with TCP.

2015-Jan-12 14:33:37 by pfc:
Currently, UPDATE_COLLECTOR_WITH_TCP = False

Should I anticipate enabling TCP updates on a pool with ~10k nodes?

2015-Jan-12 14:34:40 by pfc:
And to circle back to my original question, how can I tell if my collector is unable to keep up with the rate of updates (with TCP or UDP), and differentiate that from dropped packets that have nothing to do with the collector itself?

2015-Jan-12 15:24:55 by gthain:
I'd run condor_status -collector -l

and look for the DaemonCoreDutyCycle parameter. This measures the percent of time servicing command handler, timers, signals and pipes, and not otherwise idle.

2015-Jan-12 16:12:36 by bbockelm:
Greg - that one can be a bit misleading as UDP may drop packets even with lower duty cycle (simply depending on update rates and socket buffer size).

PFC - personally, I go with TCP updates. In such case, I find it easier to debug load issues. In the case of TCP updates, Greg's advice is bulletproof.

See also #5170: condor_reconfig zeros update SequenceNumber, looks like dropped update which may have been exacerbating this problem.
